Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Facets just above the Thanksgiving crust surprised me how readily they popped with only light wrist taps in the ECT. This layer isn't everywhere because strong winds blew before it was capped with new snow on Dec 3. These winds likely removed this layer on top of the crust. No matter, the next week of high pressure and cold temps will create more weak layers and facets.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Nothing notable in this pit except old except there was only 5 cm of old, hard snow. It will be interesting to see if snow on this aspect (SW) develops nsf's this week during high pressure and cold air temperatures.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: No Thermometer - air temp approx minus 15 deg Celsius Smooth alpine feature just below ridge. Slightly wind loaded

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Storm 4 incoming. Visual observation from around the resort shows upper and only a few mid elev northerly asp slopes are holding a snowpack. Solar asp all the way to upper elev have little to no snow. All SR158 start zones and tracks are void of snow prior to Storm 4.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This profile has multiple layers of concern. All the crust/facet combinations are troublesome. The crusts are 3 to 4 cm thick and very supportable. Each could be a bed surface on its own. However, future loading will determine which one and how deep failure occurs. It seems this matrix could support quite a bit of weight before it goes.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Historical pit location for Rendezvous Bowl. Layer of concern is at 75-65cm and is sandwiched between 2 crust. Kirk Speckhals observing.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Although pit is within ski boundary, resort is not open yet. No snowmaking, grooming has impacted site. 20 cm of new unconsolidated low moisture snow fell last night and is sitting on top of a fairly homogeneous frozen slab 60 cm thick, which has a weak layer at the ground. Shovel pull on remaining column after ECT released entire column as block all the way to the ground. see photos.

Increasing winds and warm temperatures have destroyed some of the surface hoar in this area. NSF's are consistent on NW-N-NE aspects in the .5mm size range.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: cold clear nights have created large surface facets leaving a 10 cm layer of faceted snow near the surface. Q1 planer fracture across whole column at 25 cm, and that fracrture piece then easily fractured as it fell at 85 cm. See photos.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: study plot

Average HS in wind sheltered areas at 9500' was ~45-50 cm with some shaded areas up to 75cm. Sled penetration was 0-5cm deep in areas with previous wind effect prior to the rain - just a little bit deeper in more sheltered areas. Pretty stable snowpack (thin as it is), but there are still sharp facets on the ground.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other; Collapsing, widespread; Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug pit just below fresh (natural) avalanche debris, likely from the night before. Widespread whumpfing and shooting cracks in the mid-elevations. Remote triggered a small avalanche from 150 - 200' away. Facets over MF crust was obvious weak layer. Some of the more reactive snow I've ever seen!

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Approximately 6" of fresh snow in last snow cycle 24 hours ago, came in warm than cooler,with wind gusts to 40 mph. Nights have been clear and cold since. Surface is sparkly facets. Snow below 80 cm is dense and wet.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Paikoin isoja määriä tuulentuomaa lunta. Alueella oli tapahtunut 2-3 vyöryä sunnuntaina 26.11. Satulassa oli molemmin puolin vyöryjäljet, laukeaminen on voinut tapahtua samalla kertaa. Tämä on laskijoiden aiheuttama. Noin 100 m itään oli kolmas vyöry. Tämä oli isoin. Ei laskujälkiä, joten se oli luultavasti luonnollinen vyöry. Lumiprofiilin kaivuupaikassa maa kivirakkaa.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; Recent activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Paikoin runsaasti uutta tuulentuomaa lunta. Alueella tapahtunut sunnuntaina 26.11 kaksi tai kolme lumivyöryä. Satulan molemmat sivut vyöryneet, laukeaminen tapahtunut laskijoiden toimesta joko erikseen tai yhtäaikaa ylätaitteesta. Isoin, erillinen vyöry noin 100 m itään. Profiilin maa kivirakkaa.

10 to 15cm storm snow in most areas with some wind loaded terrain up to 30cm deep. In the mid morning hours, winds switched to NW/N and were scouring previously wind loaded terrain. Winds tapered by mid day with increasing low level cloud cover.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

User.name: David Reichel
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Rain event in past week created crust which will bear watching. New snow has bonded well, with only minor dry loose activity with ski cuts on steep test slopes >40 degrees. Obvious ridge-top plumes above 10000' indicate potentially significant wind slabs at high elevations, NE thru SE aspects.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Test pit on slope between Independence Mine workings and Gold Cord basin. Observed wind slab on M/F crust. CT14, Q1@45cm. ECT14@45cmwith no propagation. 1.3C change/10cm snow depth thru lower 70cm of profile. Enough to cause faceting in lower snowpack.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: No tests performed, good structure/pack condition

100' from Glory summit on the breakover. This is a standard pit location for observing early season snowpack structure. We dug near here in early October and were tracking some basal facets at that point. Today they are rounding and well bonded to the snow above. Even when the ECT column tipped over into the pit it wouldn't break apart.

One ect propagated after 5 full body swings after the loading steps were completed, it propagated below the ice layer at 35cm. The ct also broke at the same interface with a Q2 fracture after one full body swing after the loading steps were completed

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Thanksgiving Day Pit. Average HS since 1986 on Thanksgiving Day = 81cm Despite a subtle collapse in the basal facets, stability was good. No CO, no CR, no AV in the area. Warm temperatures were atypical of this time of year. Many non-shaded aspects were sopping wet top to bottom.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Slope had been shot with a 2lb explosive that day with no result. Overall stability good. Higher elevation NE aspects avalanching on basal instabilities, reactive to explosives. Current weather pattern looking good for healing trend.
Deep and stable snowpack. Great for Nov 21st. CPST 19/100 SF

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit was dug a few meters below ridgetop in an area that sees relatively large amount of wind loading

It was difficult to find both a slab and weak layer. This was a wind loaded spot and had some weak snow at the ground. Other places lacked a slab but had weaker snow near the ground. I suspect you could still trigger an avalanche in a few places. Certainly you could other places at slightly higher elevation that had more early season snow, colder temperatures and more wind with the most recent storm.

Dug 2 pits at different locations to examine the basal facets in this area of Relay Peak. The facets were slightly more advanced at the higher elevation but were still not reactive to snowpack tests that show propagation.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug 2 snowprofiles in this area at different elevations to examine the basal facets. At this elevation, the facets were moist and rounding and were not reactive to snowpack tests.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Tour up access road and onto runout fans. No activity seen other than one D1 point release on S aspect near 9500'. Small cornice and prior minor wind loading apparent on E aspects along 9000' ridgeline above pit site.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Aspects range from roughly 320 deg to 40 deg. This avalanche broke over 2000 feet wide. It failed on a layer of small facets at 55 cm.

Rain on new snow overnight. Snow surface conditions were a variety of crusts on shaded aspects that were mostly ski supportable but some breakable. On solar aspects, soft snow existed with mostly shallow snowpack conditions.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The surface snow was damp from the sunshine and warm temps, up to 10,000 on the solar aspects. Wet loose, natural activity noted as well.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Widespread surface hoar and near-surface faceting, particularly on north aspects. Much of the top 10-20 cm of the snow is beginning to facet. The crust layers near the base were all decomposing. Basal facets becoming moist -- can form into snowballs.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: There was an air pocket between the ice crust that formed the bottom layer and the ground. The column failed when the ice broke free from the little ground that it was attached to, a small root and rock at the back of the column. Our layer of concern was the old September snow, which showed no sign of instability at its interface. It is hard to interpret the ectp as a sign of instability, it seemed to be more an issue of ground condition specifically beneath the column and not an indicator of overall instability at the ground.

Snowfall totals for the Haines Pass were much lower than the coastal region from the precip event Friday. Saturday strong northerly outflow drifted any new deposits into windslab or soft sastrugi. Noticeable sun crust also forming.

Snowfall totals for the Haines Pass were much lower than the coastal region which received 20-25cm, from the precip event Friday. Saturday strong northerly outflow drifted any new deposits into soft windslab or sastrugi. Noticeable sun crust also forming.
Very wind loaded slope - significantly more loaded than any other slope we encountered

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent activity on different slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Shady, high elevation aspect. Upper half of snowpack is from storm last weekend. Lower half is series of Sep. to October storms. Obvious signs of instability (i.e., avalanches, cracking, collapsing) confined to recently wind load slopes. Propagation in layer of depth hoar on this slope urges caution/avoidance on steep slopes holding snow from last month.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ended up skiing NE bowl off true summit rather than this chute. Careful slow turns with minimal damage to the skis' bases!

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Recent activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug in the crown of an avalanche from 10/3/17. Steep slope with a wind loaded pocket from W winds. Looked like possible skier triggered.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug 100 feet below summit, in wide NNW couloir. Pre-season (summer/fall) storm dropped 3-5' of snow over last week, came in warm and dense with strong wind, bonded well. Have observed widespread 10-20cm rain/melt crust on ground that formed at start of storm. This layer is moist in some pits and well bonded to warm/moist snow above. No sign of collapse (or shear). Main concern is fresh wind load.

Eagles Nest fracture profile done by Michel, the bed surface is 10cm above our 2 of july crust and it is a small layer of SH 4-5mm.

LADERA DE LA BIBLIOTECA, ESTA SE AVALANCHA DE FORMA NATURAL Y CAE SOBRE LA RUTA INTERNACIONAL CH-115, SE REALIZA LA CALICATA 36 HRS DESPUES DE TERMINADO EL MAL TIEMPO DEL DIA DOMINGO 13 DE AGOSTO. SE OBSERVAN ALGUNAS AVALANCHAS NATURALES, EN ALGUNAS LADERAS EXISTEN CORNISAS DE ACUMULACION POR VIENTO QUE PRESENTAN PEQUEÑAS AVALANCHAS NATURALES Y OTRAS DE PIONT RELEASE. NO SE REALIZA OBSERVACION DE LOS GRANOS.

LA TORMENTA CESO HACE MENOS DE 24 HRS. EN ESTA OCACION NO SE OBSERVARON LOS GRANOS DE NIEVE.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit by Irene Henninger, Charlotte (CP), Tom and Joe-Polytech :) CT12 had energy but 1/2 broke above one crust and other half beneath it (1cm height difference). Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The bottom layer of depth hoar (23-13cm) is my greatest layer of concerns at the moment. It's hard to stress this deep weak layer but it can lead to high consequences. ECT failed on this layer (24) with propagation to the entire column. The surface hoar layer within the snowpack (68-65cm) isn't a big issue at the moment in this particular area as the layer above (DF) is not stiff enough to create a slab. This SH layer can be a real problem in lee to the W1/2 start zones with wind affected snow if still present.
Pit by Irene Henninger. Snowpack HS ranging across uppper half of slope around 150cm. Bottom 1/3 HS around 60cm.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: pit by Robbie Williams: ECTN21 continued process on ECT28 propagated entire length of block Sudden Planar in nature, down 27 running on buried surface hoar.
hasty pit did not have time to identify crystals of weak layer - possible small SH. A top heavy structure but fairly stable at present.
Prev strong - gale SE winds 170721
Wind trended S E-SE with the approaching front from 3pm, skies became obscured and light snow at 1800m. HS varied on slope from 35-140cm

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: SP: 6 cm

This snowpit was dug just outside the Bridger Bowl Ski Area's southern boundary in an open meadow with a snowman. PS/PF: 5cm/25cm HS:139cm HSW:510.6mm Layer 139-126: SWE=22.1mm Layer 126-110: SWE=57.6mm Layer 110-94: SWE=68.8mm Layer 94-79: SWE=58.5mm Layer 79-75: SWE=15.6mm Layer 75-45: SWE=117mm Layer 45-0: SWE=171mm
